sen.j: 福原京（ふくはらきょう）は、平安時代末期の治承4年（1180年）、計画のみに終った和田京に続いて、平清盛の主導で造営が進められた日本の首都の通称。
sen.e: Fukuhara-kyo is the name of the Japanese capital, establishment of which was promoted by TAIRA no Kiyomori in 1180, in end of Heian period, after a plan of building Wada-kyo ended up without implemented.
Fukuhara-kyo is the name of a capital city which TAIRA no Kiyomori wanted to establish and promoted after a plan to build Wada-kyo had ended in failure 1180 (towards the end of Heian period)
Fukuhara-kyo is the name of a capital city which TAIRA no Kiyomori wanted to establish and promoted after a plan to build Wada-kyo had ended in failure 1180 (towards the end of Heian period).

sen.j: 場所は現在の兵庫県神戸市中央区 (神戸市)から兵庫区北部にあたり、平氏の拠点のひとつである貿易港の大輪田泊（現在の兵庫港・神戸港西部）に人工島の経が島（経ヶ島）を築き整備拡張した港を見下ろす山麓に都を置くことが計画された。
sen.e: The place where Fukuhara-kyo was going to be built is the area from Chuo Ward, Kobe City, Hyogo Prefecture through the northern Hyogo Ward, and it was planned to establish the capital at the foot of the mountain from which a well-maintained and expanded port could be seen, by constructing Kyogashima Island, an artificial island, in Owada no tomari (Owada port) (current Hyogo Port/the western Kobe Port), which was one of the base trading ports for the Taira clan.

The plan was build Fukuhara-kyo in an area extending from Chuo Ward, Kobe City, Hyogo Prefecture to northern Hyogo Ward. It would stand at the foot of a mountain looking down over an expanded Owada no Tomari (present-day Hyogo Port/western Kobe Port)), a trading port and one of the bases of the Taira clan, where an artifical island named Kyogashima Island was to be built.
sen.cmt: Natural English. Split into two sentences.
sen.e: The plan was build Fukuhara-kyo in an area extending from Chuo Ward, Kobe City, Hyogo Prefecture to northern Hyogo Ward, and it would stand at the foot of a mountain looking down over an expanded Owada no Tomari (present-day Hyogo Port/western Kobe Port), a trading port and one of the bases of the Taira clan, where an artificial island named Kyogashima Island was to be built.
sen.cmt: 一訳文に戻しました。スペル)削除

sen.j: 平清盛は、高倉天皇と平家一門の反対を押し切って遷都を強行したが、それは宋 (王朝)との貿易拡大によって海洋国家の樹立を目指したためともいわれ、都市整備が進めば平氏政権による「福原幕府」のようなものになったとも言われる。
sen.e: TAIRA no Kiyomori went ahead with the transfer of the capital over objections from Emperor Takakura and the Taira family, and it is said that he was aiming for the establishment of a maritime state through trade expansion with Sung and if the urban development had been promoted, a powerful feudal government, which might have been called "Fukuhara Bakufu" under the control of the Taira clan, would have been established.

TAIRA no Kiyomori forced through his plan for the transfer of the capital, despite objections from Emperor Takakura and the Taira family. It is said that he was aiming to establish a maritime state by expanding trade with the Sung (dynasty), and that if the city had been built, a powerful feudal government under the control of the Taira clan, a kind of "Fukuhara Bakufu", would have been established.
sen.cmt: Natural English. Split into two sentences.
sen.e: TAIRA no Kiyomori forced through his plan for the transfer of the capital, despite objections from Emperor Takakura and the Taira family, and it is said that he was aiming to establish a maritime state by expanding trade with the Sung (dynasty), and that if the city had been built, a powerful feudal government under the control of the Taira clan, a kind of 'Fukuhara Bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun)', would have been established.
sen.cmt: 一訳文に戻しました。原文の「」に合わせ"を'に「幕府」注釈補足

sen.j: 福原京の建造物群は源義仲によって全て焼き払われた。
sen.e: However, the groups of buildings of Fukuhara-kyo were completely burned down by MINAMOTO no Yoshinaka.
However, the groups of buildings of Fukuhara-kyo were completely burned down by MINAMOTO no Yoshinaka.

sen.j: 治承4年（1180年）6月2日、京都から摂津国の福原へ安徳天皇・高倉上皇・後白河法皇の行幸が行なわれ、ここに行宮が置かれた。
sen.e: On June 2, 1180, gyoko (Emperor's going out) of Emperor Antoku, the retired Emperor Takakura, and the Cloistered Emperor Goshirakawa was implemented from Kyoto to Fukuhara, Settsu Province, and accordingly, an Angu (temporary lodging built to accommodate an Imperial visit) was built here.

On June 2, 1180, Emperor Antoku, the retired Emperor Takakura, and the Cloistered Emperor Goshirakawa left Kyoto on an Imperial visit to Fukuhara, Settsu Province, and an Angu (temporary lodging) was built in Fukuhara to accommdate them.

On June 2, 1180, Emperor Antoku, the retired Emperor Takakura, and the Cloistered Emperor Goshirakawa left Kyoto on an Imperial visit to Fukuhara, Settsu Province, and an Angu (temporary lodging) was built in Fukuhara to accommodate them.

sen.j: そして平氏政権は福原に隣接する和田（輪田）の地に「和田京」の造営を計画した。
sen.e: After this, the Taira clan administration planned an establishment of "Wada-kyo" in the land of Wada which bordered on Fukuhara.
The Taira clan administration further planned to establish "Wada-kyo" in Wada, a territory which bordered on Fukuhara.
sen.cmt: It is not really clear what "this" of "After this" is referring to. I think this sentences is describing another thing that the Taira were planning to do, not something which happed later.
sen.e: The Taira clan administration further planned to establish 'Wada-kyo' in Wada, a territory which bordered on Fukuhara.
sen.cmt: 原文の「」に合わせ"を'にスペース削除

sen.j: 和田は現在の兵庫区南部から長田区にまたがる地域にあたる。
sen.e: Wada is the area across from current southern Hyogo Ward to Nagata Ward.
Wada is the area extending from present-day South Hyogo Ward to Nagata Ward.
Wada is the area extending from present-day South Hyogo Ward to Nagata Ward.

sen.j: 当初平安京と同様の条坊制による都市を建設しようとしたが、和田は平地が少なく手狭だったため、すぐにこの計画は行き詰まってしまった。
sen.e: At the beginning of the plan, the government was going to build a capital with the same street plan as Heian-kyo (the ancient capital of Japan in current Kyoto), but since the land of Wada was not big enough and thus the plan soon got bogged down.
The plan was to build a capital with the same street plan as Heian-kyo (ancient capital and present-day Kyoto), but the land of Wada was not big enough and the plan soon got bogged down.
The plan was to build a capital with the same street plan as Heian-kyo (ancient capital and present-day Kyoto), but the land of Wada was not broad enough and the plan soon got bogged down.

sen.j: そこで同じ摂津国の昆陽野（兵庫県伊丹市）、更には播磨国印南野（兵庫県加古川市）に新しい京を造営する話が持ち上がったが、どちらの話も立ち消えとなり、7月には福原をしばらく皇居とし、道路を開通させて親平氏派の一部の人々に限り宅地が与えられることになった。
sen.e: So proposals to build the new capital in Koyano (Itami City, Hyogo Prefecture), Settsu Province and in Inamino (Kakogawa City, Hyogo Prefecture), Harima Province came up but soon ended up in smoke, and thus Fukuhara was used as the land for the Imperial Palace temporarily in July and some roads were opened at the same time, allowing only a part of people who were pro-Taira clan to have a land to live.

Proposals were then made to build the new capital in Koyano (Itami City, Hyogo Prefecture), Settsu Province and then in Inamino (Kakogawa City, Hyogo Prefecture), Harima Province but these came to nothing, and in July the Imperial Palace was temporarily set up in Fukuhara. Some roads were built and land was granted for houses to some Taira clan associates.

Proposals were then made to build the new capital in Koyano (Itami City, Hyogo Prefecture), Settsu Province and then in Inamino (Kakogawa City, Hyogo Prefecture), Harima Province but these came to nothing, and in July the Imperial Palace was temporarily set up in Fukuhara, and some roads were built and land was granted for houses to some Taira clan associates.

sen.j: しかし当時幼い安徳天皇に代わり院政を行なっていた高倉上皇は平安京（京都）を放棄せず、福原には離宮を建て、内裏や八省は必要ないとした。
sen.e: However, the retired Emperor Takakura, who was leading Insei (rule by the retired Emperor) instead of the Emperor Antoku who was a young child then, did not throw aside Heian-kyo (ancient Kyoto), built a rikyu (an imperial villa) in Fukuhara, and insisted that a Dairi (Imperial Palace) and Hassho (eight ministries and agencies) were not needed.

However, the retired Emperor Takakura, who was governing by Insei (rule by the retired Emperor) in place of the Emperor Antoku who was still a young child, did not abandon Heian-kyo (ancient Kyoto), but built a rikyu (an imperial villa) in Fukuhara and insisted that a Dairi (Imperial Palace) and Hassho (eight ministries and agencies) were not needed there.

However, the retired Emperor Takakura, who was governing by Insei (rule by the retired Emperor) in place of the Emperor Antoku who was still a young child, did not abandon Heian-kyo (ancient Kyoto), but built a rikyu (an imperial villa) in Fukuhara and insisted that a Dairi (Imperial Palace) and Hassho (eight ministries and agencies) were not needed there.

sen.j: これに対して平清盛は、内裏は移建せず、11月の新嘗祭までに私的に皇居を造営し、2年後には八省などの役所もつくるという方針で構えた。
sen.e: Although TAIRA no Kiyomori did not move and rebuild the Dairi, he made a policy of building the Imperial Palace personally by the Niiname-sai festival (ceremonial offering by the Emperor of newly-harvested rice to the deities) in November and building the government offices including Hassho in two years.

TAIRA no Kiyomori countered by not moving the Dairi, personally supervising the construction of a Palace in time for the Niiname-sai festival (ceremonial offering by the Emperor of newly-harvested rice to the deities) in November and building the Hassho and other government offices in the following two years.
sen.cmt: It is not clear where Kiyomori built the Imperial palace or Hassho. I assume that they were built in Fukuhara, but this needs checking.
sen.e: TAIRA no Kiyomori countered by not moving the Dairi, personally supervising the construction of a Palace in time for the Niiname-sai festival (ceremonial offering by the Emperor of newly-harvested rice to the deities) in November and building the Hassho and other government offices in the following two years.

sen.j: そして11月には皇居に似せて造られた清盛の私邸が天皇に提供され、17日から20日に新嘗祭の五節のみが行なわれると（新嘗祭自体は京都で行なわれた）、23日には京都への還幸となった。
sen.e: Then in November, the personal residence of Kiyomori, which had been built in the image of the Imperial Palace, was offered to the Emperor, and on the 17th through 20th, only Gosechi (annual court ceremony of girls music) was executed as a part of the Niiname-sai festival (the new Niiname-sai festival itself was held in Kyoto), and Kanko (Emperor to go back home) to Kyoto was held on 23rd.

Then in November, Kiyomori gave the palace, which he had built in the image of the Imperial Palace, to the Emperor, and from the 17th through 20th held the Gosechi (annual court ceremony of girls music) part of the Niiname-sai festival there (a new Niiname-sai festival was held in Kyoto), with the Emperor returning to Kyoto on the 23rd.
sen.cmt: The Japanese is unclear. Was this the end of Fukuhara as a capital??? What is the conclusion to the story???
